Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Wake Induced by a Group of Seal Whiskers: Implication to High-sensitivity Underwater Flow Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
High-sensitivity underwater flow sensors are critical for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) to navigate through dark, cramped, and unstable terrain where vision-based and sonar sensors do not function well. Harbor seals are found to be able to track their prey by capturing even minute disturbance of the ambient water solely by using their whiskers. This is attributed to the exceptional capability of seal whiskers to suppress vortex-induced vibration in the wake flow. This project will conduct flow experiments of seal whiskers at Pohang University of Science and Technology University (POSTECH) in South Korea, under the mentorship of Professor Sang Joon Lee. The collaboration provides flow facilities and equipment to obtain unique data that will enable new insights into the wake structure of multiple seal whiskers and its implication to design high-sensitivity underwater flow sensors.

Many researchers have studied the effects of key parameters of the whisker morphology on wake structure with idealized whisker-like models. However, due to the natural variation in length, size and twist along the length of seal whiskers, it is not well understood how a real seal whisker changes wake flow, in particular the vortex shedding. It is also unclear how a group of whiskers with a certain configuration interact with each other to affect the wake properties. Lack of knowledge of the wake structure generated by multiple seal whiskers in a group hinders the capability to design whisker-inspired high-sensitivity underwater flow sensors. The goal of this research is to understand the wake of multiple seal whiskers of various configurations at the Reynolds number similar to which harbor seal whiskers are subject to. Experiments will be conducted in a water tunnel using Particle Imaging Velocimetry (PIV). The results will provide insights of how individual wakes interact with each other and if the interaction is beneficial to suppress the vortex shedding. This research will fill the gap of understanding the wake structure that multiple real seal whiskers create. Ultimately knowledge will be used to develop high-sensitivity underwater flow sensors for AUVs operating in a complex environment.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From June 13th to August 11th, 2017 I participated in the East Asia Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) in Korea at Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH). My host researcher was Dr. Sang Joon Lee the director of the Biofluid and Biomimic Research Center (BBRC) at POSTECH. Through the EAPSI program I was able to travel abroad and make professional connections that otherwise would not have happened and I was also fortunate enough to be able to participate in an international conference on Particle Imaging Velocimetry while I was in Korea.

The research I conducted while I was in Korea provided valuable results for my master's thesis research which is in the up and coming field of biomimicry. Biomimicry is the study of nature's designs which have been perfected over thousands of years and how those designs can be implemented to solve engineering problems. One engineering problem is for autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). In dark, cramped, and unstable terrain AUVs are not able to maneuver using visual and sonar-based navigation. Hence, it is critical to use underwater flow sensors to accurately detect minute disturbances in the surroundings. The nature inspired design I am using are seal whiskers because seals have shown an exceptional capability to precisely track prey fish upstream using solely their whiskers. Previous research indicates this is due to the three-dimensional shape of the whiskers which have a unique wavy or undulating structure composed of peak and trough locations on both the major and minor axes. Studies have been conducted with whisker like models but we do not know how the undulating structure of a real seal reduces the vibrations the whiskers experience. The goal of the research is to understand how the wake is affected by a real seal whisker.

For my thesis I am using Particle Imaging Velocimetry or PIV to analyze the wake structure behind an undulating elephant seal whisker and behind a smooth California sea lion whisker when mounted in a water channel, with steady flow conditions. PIV uses a camera and laser system to capture the movement of particles in the water in a series of images which are then processed to obtain the velocity and energy of the wake.

Through my research I have found that the undulating whisker shows reduced vibrations in comparison to the smooth whisker for the same flow conditions and angle of attack of the whisker has a significant effect on the wake. The angle of attack is defined as 0 degrees when the minor axis is faced into the inflow and 90 degrees when the major axis is faced into the inflow. The results show that the vortex shedding frequency is reduced for both the undulating and smooth whiskers at an angle of attack of 90 degrees in comparison to 0 degrees, and the energy of the wake is much higher at an angle of attack of 90 degrees in comparison to 0 degrees. It was also found that the recovery time for the wake of the undulating whisker was significantly less than that of the smooth whisker.

With the help of the graduate students at BBRC and Dr. Lee I gained a deeper understanding of how to setup experiments to capture the desired data, how to address experimental issues when they arise, and new ways to analyze my results so that more information can be gathered. I have also been able to present my findings at the 70th Annual APS DFD conference and publish my findings in the Journal of Visualization. Through EAPSI and my research I am gaining an understanding of the effect that a real seal whisker's structure has on the wake flow, enhancing my professional career, and my professional connections.

 


Last Modified: 03/15/2018
Modified by: Jodi C Turk
